description.narrative: The aim of the initiative is maximizing the impact of migration on the socio-economic development through an improved institutional framework and engaged Diaspora.

participating-org.narrative: SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

provider-org.narrative: SWISS AGENCY FOR DEVELOPMENT AND COOPERATION - SDC

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: 1.Number of institutional, policy and legal/regulatory amendments for an efficient management of labour migration and the protection of migrants’ rights developed in a participatory manner and submitted for endorsement. 2. Number of labour migrants using efficient private recruitment abroad services, in compliance with the upgraded policy/legal framework 3. Number of representatives of national stakeholders with enhanced SKAT to develop, implement and monitor the provisions of the upgraded legal framework on labour migration management 4. Number of representatives of private agencies with improved SKAT to provide recruitment services in line with ethical, local and international standards 5. Number of NEA/TEA staff with improved SKAT to act as pro-active facilitators and provide consultative support for labour migration 6. Number of TEAs offices with upgraded model of services, aiming at improving quality and access to employment services to labour migrants, developed and endorsed (including upgraded regulations and operations guidelines, and physical infrastructure), and implemented 7. Number of people, including labour migrants, who use upgraded and improved services provided by 2 target – TEAs 8. Number of target communities that improved local services and offered complex income-generating activities and opportunities at local level as a result of implemented local development initiatives, engaging community members, including migrants 9. Number of newly selected LPAs and local actors, including migrants, with improved their SKAT on participatory local planning, integrated local development, migration and development and evidence based local policy making 10. Number of new local development initiatives implemented 11. Number of beneficiaries of new implemented local development initiatives. 12. comment.narrative: 1. 3 national policy/legal documents containing labour migration related provisions enforced 2. 0 3. 0 4. 0 5. 50 NEA/TEAs staff capacitated to provide reintegration support to returnees. 6. 0 7. N/A – to be determined after the selection of the local offices to undergo modernization process 8. 38 communities (pilot LPAs under phase 1) 9. 190 LPAs representatives (under MiDL phase 1) 10. 55 (in phase 1) 11. 310,000 beneficiaries (in phase 1) 12. 9900 (in phase 1) 13. 3800 (in phase 1) 14. 38 (in phase 1) 15. 45,000 (in phase 1) 16. 139 (in phase 1)

1.1.1) Two evidence-based institutional, policy/legal and normative amendments/regulations proposals on labour migration formulated and submitted for endorsement; 1.1.2) 1000 labour migrants using employment services provided by the private recruitment agencies, in full compliance with the legal framework; 1.1.3) N/A in 2019 1.2.1) N/A in 2019 1.2.2) 40 NEA/TEA staff capacitated to act as migration focal points 1.2.3) N/A in 2019 1.2.4) 100 beneficiaries used improved TEAs services 2.1.1) 25 communities improved local services and offered complex income-generating activities and opportunities at local level as a result of implemented local development initiatives, engaging community members, including migrants 2.1.2) 250 newly selected LPAs representatives and local actors, including migrants, with improved capacities to implement new integrated local development initiatives, taking into account gender specifics at each stage. 2.1.3) N/A in 2019 2.1.4) N/A in 2019 2.1.5) N/A in 2019 2.1.6) 2500 local community members (50% women), including migrants (50%), vulnerable groups (20%), successfully consulted/voted via online and offline tools on new local priorities, needs and solutions 2.2.1) 10 HTAs successfully implement local development schemes and 40 HTAs members (40% women) capacitated on project writing, fundraising, communication and M&E 2.2.2) 10,000 people (50% women) will benefit directly and indirectly of HTAs small projects implemented in migrants’ native localities 2.2.3) Additional 25 localities from Moldova replicate and have the capacities to implement, via CALM, the SDC/UNDP model of migrants’ engagement in local development

1.1.1) Six legal documents amendments proposals in the field of labour migration drafted and submitted to the Government for endorsement 1.1.2) 5686 labour migrants (including 35,6 % women, and 71.8% from rural areas) accessed employment services provided by the private recruitment agencies, in full compliance with the legal framework 1.1.3)10 representatives, including 8 women, of central public authorities improved knowledge and capacities of labour migration management 1.2.1) 29 representatives (including 21 women) of private recruitment agencies initiated in the international standards and principles of ethical recruitment and labour migration management 1.2.2) 80 NEA/TEA staff, including 92% women, managers and specialists, capacitated to act as migration focal points for labour migrants as part of Labour Migration School Program 1.2.3) Re-engineered employment services provided by one local employment agency (from Chisinau municipality) co-designed with end-user, model in advanced stages of construction 1.2.4) 2731 unemployed people (including 1367 women) benefited from employment support offered by the Chisinau employment office that underwent service re-engineering in 2019 2.1.1) 35 target communities selected based on an open competition in 2019 2.1.2) 385 representatives of LPAs and HTAs improved capacity, skills and knowledge to implement local development initiatives by engaging migrants 2.1.3) N/A in 2019 2.1.4) N/A in 2019 2.1.5) N/A in 2019 2.1.6) 5389 community members consulted online and offline (including 60% women, 53% migrants and 20% vulnerable groups; as well as 889 local business people, out of which 33% women and 28% young people) by the local public authorities and HTAs on the local priority needs and solutions for local public services improvement and local economic development 2.2.1) 44 HTAs successfully implemented small and medium scale local development initiatives, and representatives of 44 HTAs (including 63% women) acquired the necessary skills, knowledge and attitudes on project writing and implementation with the diaspora, fundraising, communication and M&E, as part of the HTA School Program 2.2.2) 77,746 people (including circa 60% women) from rural areas benefited directly from 44 HTA small and medium scale projects, developed and implemented jointly with migrants originating from those communities 2.2.3) Additional 39 new localities from Moldova capacitated via CALM and UNDP support schemes and replicated the model of migrants’ engagement in the development of local communities.

1.1.1. One evidence-based institutional, policy/legal and normative amendments/regulations proposals on labour migration formulated and submitted for endorsement 1.1.2. 1,100 labour migrants using employment services provided by the private recruitment agencies, in full compliance with the legal framework 1.1.3. 40 representatives of national stakeholders with skills, knowledge, attitude and training to develop, implement and monitor the provisions of the upgraded legal framework on labour migration management
1.2.1. 20 representatives of private agencies have improved their SKAT to follow local and international recruitment standards 1.2.2. 40 representatives of the NEA/TEA are capacitated to act as migration focal points 1.2.3. N/A in 2021 1.2.4. 200 beneficiaries, including labor migrants, use upgraded and improved services provided by target TEAs
2.1.1. 25 communities improve local services and offer complex income-generating activities and opportunities at local level, as a result of implemented local development initiatives engaging community members, including migrants 2.1.2. 250 newly selected LPAs representatives and local actors, including migrants, have improved capacities to implement new integrated local development initiatives, taking into account gender specifics at each stage. 2.1.3. 10 new local development initiatives are successfully implemented and fully functional, answering to the needs of community members, including migrants and their relatives, women and the most vulnerable groups 2.1.4. 30,000 people (of which at least 50% women) benefit from new local initiatives, which take into account the specific needs of all community members (including migrants and their relatives, women, children, youth, elderly and vulnerable groups) 2.1.5. 750 community members (of which 50% women and 80% migrants) financially and non-financially support new local development initiatives 2.1.6. N/A in 2021
2.2.1. 10 HTAs successfully implement local development schemes and 27 HTA members (of which at least 40% women) are capacitated on project writing, fundraising, communication and M&E 2.2.2. 10,000 people (of which at least 50% women) benefit from the implementation by HTAs of small projects in their native localities 2.2.3. 25 additional localities from Moldova replicate and have the capacities to implement, via CALM, the SDC/UNDP model of migrants’ engagement in local development
2.3.1. N/A in 2021 2.3.2. N/A in 2021

1.1.1. Two institutional and policy/legal amendments/regulations on labour migration formulated and endorsed. Government Decision no. 78/2021 on adoption of secondary legislation and Order of the Ministry of Education no. 309/2021 resulting in the institutionalization of 4 new skills validation centers. 1.1.2. 6,272 labour migrants were assisted by private recruitment agencies to secure a job abroad, in compliance with the upgraded legal framework (entered into force in May 2021), of which 2,187 women migrants (35%) and 4,338 migrants residing in rural areas (69%). 1.1.3. 18 representatives of national stakeholders (33% women) have increased their skills, knowledge, attitude and training to develop, implement and monitor the provisions of the upgraded legal framework on labour migration management.
1.2.1. 22 representatives of private agencies (77% women) have improved their SKAT to follow local and international recruitment standards (IRIS standard operations and provisions of the amended legislation in the field of labour migration). 1.2.2. 94 representatives of the NEA/TEA have been capacitated to act as migration focal points and improved their capacity to engage online with beneficiaries and to provide employment reintegration support. 1.2.3. Two NEA territorial offices have upgraded models of services for labour migrants (Chisinau office – operation since late 2020 and Soroca office – reconstructed and scheduled for reopening in 2022). 1.2.4. 5,836 people (of which 46% women), including 10 returned migrants (of which 60% women), benefited from employment support provided by the NEA office in Chisinau.
2.1.1. 28 (out of the initially 35 pre-selected) communities are promoting systemic local economic development and services improvement interventions, based on a meaningful community engagement process (including of diaspora representatives). 2.1.2. 653 local stakeholders have improved their SKAT on participatory planning and integrated local development, a result of the Project’s capacity building programs and thematic training organized in 2021. 2.1.3. 27 community and local public service development projects initiated by HTAs in partnership with LPAs (15 HTA Incubator, 5 HTA Accelerator and 7 DAR 1+3 projects). 2.1.4. Local economic development projects enhance income opportunities for 174,861 beneficiaries from 25 communities, of which 51% women and 27% youth. 2.1.5. 3,308 community members, including migrants, have supported the new local development initiatives (via 26 crowdfunding campaigns launched). 2.1.6. 3,769 local community members, including 1,378 migrants, consulted on new local priorities and needs (of which 50.8% women).
2.2.1. 15 new HTAs capacitated in 2021 to implement small local development schemes independently. Cumulative number of 97 HTAs developed their capacities and acquired experience to liaise diaspora for local development. 84 HTA members (of which 80% women) have been capacitated on project writing, fundraising, communication and M&E. 2.2.2. 107,947 beneficiaries of the 27 small local development projects implemented by HTAs, of which 55,776 women (51.7%). 2.2.3. 55 localities from Moldova were consulted and replicated best practices on integrating DMD and project management into local development initiatives (in 16 localities – new HTAs established).
2.3.1. N/A Activities to be conducted in 2022. 2.3.2. N/A Activities to be conducted in 2022.

1.1.1) Two evidence-based institutional, policy/legal and normative amendments/regulations proposals on labour migration formulated and submitted for endorsement 1.1.2) 1050 labour migrants using employment services provided by the private recruitment agencies, in full compliance with the legal framework 1.1.3) 40 representatives of national stakeholders with skills, knowledge, attitude and training to develop, implement and monitor the provisions of the upgraded legal framework on labour migration management 1.2.1) 20 representatives of private agencies to provide recruitment services in line with ethical, local and international standards 1.2.2) 40 NEA/TEA staff capacitated to act as migration focal points 1.2.3) 1 local employment agency provides upgraded services 1.2.4) 200 beneficiaries, including labour migrants who use upgraded and improved services provided by target TEAs 2.1.1) 25 communities improved local services and offered complex income-generating activities and opportunities at local level as a result of implemented local development initiatives, engaging community members, including migrants 2.1.2) 250 newly selected LPAs representatives and local actors, including migrants, with improved capacities to implement new integrated local development initiatives, taking into account gender specifics at each stage. 2.1.3) 10 new local development initiatives successfully implemented and fully functional, answering to the needs of community members, including migrants and their relatives, women and the most vulnerable groups 2.1.4) 30,000 people benefit (at least 50% women), directly and indirectly as a result of new local initiatives, taking into account the specific needs of all community members, including migrants and their relatives, women, children, youth, elderly and vulnerable groups; 2.1.5) 750 community members (50% women, 80% migrants) successfully supported financially and non-financially new local development initiatives 2.1.6) N/A in 2020 2.2.1) 15 HTAs successfully implement local development schemes and 40 HTAs members (40% women) capacitated on project writing, fundraising, communication and M&E 2.2.2) 10,000 people (50% women) will benefit directly and indirectly of HTAs small projects implemented in migrants’ native localities 2.2.3) Additional 25 localities from Moldova replicate and have the capacities to implement, via CALM, the SDC/UNDP model of migrants’ engagement in local development

1.1.1.Two legal documents - the legislative amendments to the Law on employment No. 105 of 14.06.2018, and to the Government Decision No. 1276 of 26.12.2018 were approved by the Moldovan Parliament, promulgated by the President of the Republic of Moldova and published in the Official Gazette No. 199-204 on 7 August 2020. These amendments will enter into force in 2021. 1.1.2.The upgraded legislative framework shall enter into force in 2021. As of midyear, 2369 migrants including 715 women (30%) were assisted by private recruitment agencies to secure a job abroad in countries like Poland, Holland, Germany and others. 1.1.3.The upgraded legislative framework shall enter into force in 2021. 1.2.1.The upgraded legislative framework shall enter into force in 2021. 1.2.2. 94 local employment office staff – migration focal points from each territorial unit and central office of NEA, improved capacity to engage online with beneficiaries and to provide employment reintegration support 1.2.3. First upgraded local employment office from Chisinau municipality offers improved employment services to migrants at all stages of migration and all other categories of jobseekers, considering the specific needs of all categories of beneficiaries. 1.2.4. 4016 beneficiaries, incl. 52% women and 93 returned migrants, benefited from employment support of Chisinau employment office 2.1.1. 46 projects initiated by HTAs in 41 communities in partnership with LPAS (as part of the HTA Incubator, HTA Accelerator 1+1, DAR 1+3, HTA junior grants programs) for local public service development 32 (out of 35 pre-selected) communities are promoting systemic local economic development and services improvement interventions, based on a broad Diaspora – engagement process. 2.1.2. 332 LPAs representatives, local actors from 83 partner communities, with improved SKAT on participatory local planning as result of the capacity building program organized in 2020. 2.1.3. 25 local economic development projects initiated in 25 target communities; 46 projects initiated by HTAs in 41 communities in partnership with LPAS (as part of the HTA Incubator, HTA Accelerator 1+1, DAR 1+3, HTA junior grants programs) for local public service development. 2.1.4. LED projects are expected to benefit circa 200 000 beneficiaries from target communities, including 48 existing business to expand, 50 new start-ups and circa 1000 new jobs to be created Local public service development projects will enhance access to local services for a total number of 201 841 beneficiaries 2.1.5. In progress. The number of people involved will be estimated at the local projects’ completion stage. 2.1.6. Over 1,500 of local stakeholders consulted on defining the economic proprieties to be supported by MiDL; 4200 community members, including migrants consulted on new local priorities to be solved in 2020 with their active participation. 2.2.1. 83 HTAs representatives (including over 50% women) fortified as local drivers liaising with the diaspora and local stakeholders in the community development process. 2.2.2. 201 841 beneficiaries expected to benefit of 46 local public service improvement projects. 2.2.3. 39 new HTAs were established in 2020

1.1.1. N/A in 2022 1.1.2. 1150 labour migrants using employment services provided by the private recruitment agencies, in full compliance with the legal framework. 1.1.3. 40 representatives of national stakeholders with skills, knowledge, attitude and training to develop, implement and monitor the provisions of the upgraded legal framework on labour migration management.
1.2.1. 20 representatives of private agencies have improved their SKAT to follow local and international recruitment standards. 1.2.2. 40 representatives of the NEA/TEA are capacitated to act as migration focal points. 1.2.3. 2 TEAs provide upgraded services. 1.2.4. 200 beneficiaries, including labor migrants, use upgraded and improved services provided by target TEAs.
2.1.1. 25 communities improve local services and offer complex income-generating activities and opportunities at local level, as a result of implemented local development initiatives engaging community members, including migrants. 2.1.2. 250 newly selected LPAs representatives and local actors, including migrants, have improved capacities to implement new integrated local development initiatives, taking into account gender specifics at each stage. 2.1.3. N/A in 2022 (results achieved in 2020 - 2021) 2.1.4. N/A in 2022 (results achieved in 2020 - 2021) 2.1.5. N/A in 2022 2.1.6. N/A in 2022
2.2.1. 10 HTAs successfully implement local development schemes and 27 HTA members (of which at least 40% women) are capacitated on project writing, fundraising, communication and M&E. 2.2.2. N/A in 2022 (results achieved in 2020 - 2021) 2.2.3. 25 additional localities from Moldova replicate and have the capacities to implement, via CALM, the SDC/UNDP model of migrants’ engagement in local development.
2.3.1. Migrants’ engagement for development methodology adapted and tailored to the context of the Transnistrian region. 2.3.2. Up to two pilot communities from the Transnistrian region engage migrants in local development.
